newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan opens door wider to China business visitors.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan opens door wider to China business visitors.

text.p: Taiwan said on Thursday it would open its door wider to businessmen from China despite Taipei's official attempts to cool local firms' fever to invest in the mainland.
The economics ministry issued a statement saying it had decided to ease rules to allow visits by China businessmen.
Current rules allow senior executives and technical staff from mainland companies to apply to visit Taiwan for business purposes for a month, with the option to extend the visit for a second month.
The relaxed rule will allow middle-level executives and technical staff to visit for business functions or training.
They will be eligible to stay in Taiwan for one month to visit or attend meetings, or for three months for training. Extensions under these terms are not allowed.
The move is expected to expand economic and trade exchanges across the Taiwan strait, the statement said.
Taiwan has banned all direct official contact with China since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949, when the Nationalists fled to the island.
Despite the ban, indirect commerce has flourished since the late 1980s, when political tensions began to thaw. About 30,000 Taiwan companies have poured more than US$20 billion into China so far.

Last week, Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui accused China of using commerce as a political lever against the island and Taiwan's top economic policymaker told local businessmen it was time to slow their investment projects in the mainland.
"Communist China is trying to use our people to coerce our government and use commerce to achieve political coercion, in order to pressure our government," Lee said.
"Faced with this situation, we must uphold the principle of exercising restraint and avoiding rashness in order to handle the current cross-straits relations," he added.

Though all investments in China must be government approved and routed indirectly through Hong Kong or other countries, Taiwan remains concerned that its economy may become too dependent on China -- and hence politically vulnerable.
President Lee said in August the island needed to review its policy of targeting China as its main market to avoid over-dependence on the mainland for investment.

Taiwan's President Enterprises said on September 12 it had abandoned plans to build a US$100 million power plant in China. It said it would instead invest more than T$30 billion (US$1.1 billion) in local projects over two years.
On August 16, Formosa Plastics Group said it was ending a deal to build what would have been the biggest Taiwanese project in China to date, a US$3 billion power plant in coastal Fujian province.
